results.title: The Round world and the sun's rays
results.creator_credit: J. Arthur Rank, Gaumont-British Instructional, Frank Wells and Louis Dahl
results.brief_description: The following fundamental facts concerning the earth are illustrated: the earth spins on its axis, making a complete turn each day. It also revolves round the sun, taking one year to complete each journey. Energy from the sun falls upon the earth and passes through the envelope of air which surrounds it. This energy is not evenly distributed, because the world is round. At the equator the sun’s rays meet the earth at right angles. At the Poles, the same amount of energy falls on a larger surface of the earth. Thus it is hot near the equator and cold at the Poles.

results.title: The Rough road to freedom
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Crossroads of the world: a study of North Africa and the Middle East”.
Describes the western influence in North Africa and the Middle East. Technology which had halted for a thousand years, spurts ahead as new revolutionary leaders, like Bourguiba, Nasser and Kassem, reogranise feudal society and restore the pride of the people and the fertility of their soil. In the drylands of the United Arab Republic you climb great engineering works which irrigate the fields, power the machinery and give light to schools and colleges where a new generation of Egyptians prepare for modern life.

results.title: The Rough and the smooth
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Otton and David Muir
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian eye V”.
Tom Roberts and Charles Conder belonged to the Heidelberg School of Australian Impressionism and the contrasting lives and work of these two artists are the subject matter of the film. The Roberts and Conder story is told through paintings, drawings, photographs and extracts from early films. Places the artists in a social and historical context within Australia and also indicates the influence of the French Impressionists upon their work. Suitable for middle and upper secondary, and tertiary levels.

results.title: The Ross family mystery
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Barry Cowling and Brian Pollard
results.brief_description: The study of genealogy is shown to be a unique method of learning history and social studies. Two teenagers set about to solve the mysterious disappearance of an ancestor from Prince Edward Island. Their detective work takes them through museums, libraries, a rectory and an abandoned house. This valuable teaching aid shows how the interest of younger students might be stimulated. Cast: Donna Anthony, Stephen Connolly, Billie Dunn, Mary Dunn, William Dunn, Bekah Gass, Rod MacIntyre

results.title: The Rose and the mignonette
results.creator_credit: A.F. Films, Co-operative Generale du Cinema Francais and Andre Michel
results.brief_description: An English version of Louis Aragon’s poem originally filmed in France, translated by Stephen Spender and spoken by Emlyn Williams. In the form of an allegory, it is a memorial to those who died in the French Resistance. Music by George Aurig. Photographed by Marice Barry le Chevallier.

results.title: The Rose
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Martin Worth, Aaron Russo and Mark Rydell
results.brief_description: Bette Midler is fantastic as a rock star, modelled on Janis Joplin, whose success as a musician cannot erase the scars of her childhood. Her descent into drugs and alcohol is detailed with an almost clinical precision, as is the callousness of the music industry. The film features a collection of wonderful set pieces where Midler performs blues-tinged rock and roll and these mesmerising musical performances act as a chorus to the drama we are watching. The cinematography is by Vilmos Zsigmond and the intelligent, adult script is co-written by Bo Goldman. Frederic Forrest and Alan Bates are excellent as the singer’s frustrated lovers, but it is Midler who is the dazzling centrepiece of this movie. In many ways she expresses the contradictory emotional and social changes women began to experience in the Vietnam Era. Songs include “The Rose”, “Stay With Me” and “When A Man Loves A Woman”.

results.title: The Rooftop hopper = Halfaouine
results.creator_credit: Cine Tele Films, France Media, Scarabee and Ferid Boughedir
results.brief_description: Noura (Selim Boughedir) lives in Halfaouine, a popular quarter of the old city of Tunis. Like many adolescent boys he wants to know more about women and he increases his knowledge through his trips to the local bathhouse with his mother. The interaction between Noura, his mother, and other women in the bathhouse makes for comic moments as well as a sharp insight into relations between the sexes in the Arab community. Cast includes Mohamed Driss, Mustafa Aduenie and Rabia Ben Abdallah. Included as part of Africa 95, a nationwide season of the arts of Africa, screened throughout the United Kingdom in 1995.

results.title: The Romantic story of Margaret Catchpole
results.brief_description: A melodrama about a young girl sentenced to transportation to New South Wales for stealing a horse to save her lover from the excise men. Cast includes Lottie Lyell, Raymond Longford, Augustus Neville, Sybil Wilde.

results.title: The Romantic period
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “English Literature”.
Illustrates the literary and political revolution that occurred in the early part of the nineteenth century. Dramatised selections from Burns, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Blake, Byron, Shelley, Keats and Scott reveal the individuality and independence of spirit of England’s Romantic writers.
